quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Event Propagation[/h1] There are two ways of event propagation in the HTML DOM: [b]bubbling [/b]and [b]capturing[/b]. Event propagation allows for the definition of the element order when an event occurs. If you have a

element inside a

element, and the user clicks on the

element, which element's "click" event should be handled first? In [b]bubbling[/b], the innermost element's event is handled first and then the outer element's event is handled. The

element's click event is handled first, followed by the

element's click event. In [b]capturing[/b], the outermost element's event is handled first and then the inner. The
element's click event is handled first, followed by the

element's click event. [note]Capturing goes [b]down [/b]the DOM. Bubbling goes [b]up [/b]the DOM.[/note]

[h1]Capturing vs. Bubbling[/h1]

The [b]addEventListener[/b]() method allows you to specify the propagation type with the "[b]useCapture[/b]" parameter.[code format="js" ]addEventListener(event, function, [b]useCapture[/b])[/code]  
The default value is [b]false[/b], which means the bubbling propagation is used; when the value is set to [b]true[/b], the event uses the capturing propagation. [code format="js" ]//Capturing propagation
elem1.addEventListener("click", myFunction, [b]true[/b]); 

//Bubbling propagation
elem2.addEventListener("click", myFunction, [b]false[/b]);[/code]
[note]This is particularly useful when you have the same event handled for multiple elements in the DOM hierarchy.[/note]
